terms.definition: Predefined conditions a deliverable must satisfy before stakeholders formally accept it. These criteria are agreed upon before work begins and establish the standard for determining whether an output is complete and acceptable.
The total cost incurred for work performed on the project up to a given point in time. Used alongside Earned Value and Planned Value to assess cost efficiency and project health.

A delivery method that embraces change and uncertainty by executing work in short cycles, continuously incorporating feedback, and adjusting plans as understanding grows. Includes agile, iterative, and incremental approaches.

A mindset grounded in values and principles that prioritizes delivering value through collaboration, transparency, and continuous improvement. Agile teams work in short cycles, respond quickly to change, and favor working solutions over heavy documentation.

A foundational document created in 2001 by software practitioners articulating four core values: individuals and interactions over processes and tools; working software over comprehensive documentation; customer collaboration over contract negotiation; and responding to change over following a plan.

Costs incurred to measure, evaluate, and audit products or services to ensure they conform to quality standards. Examples include testing, inspections, and audits. Appraisal costs are a component of Cost of Quality.

A factor treated as true or certain for planning purposes without verification or proof. Assumptions introduce risk when they prove false and should be documented and revisited throughout the project life cycle.

A project document that captures all identified assumptions and constraints throughout the project. It is continuously updated as new information emerges to help the team monitor factors that could affect outcomes.

An ongoing collaborative activity in agile projects where the team reviews, clarifies, estimates, and reprioritizes product backlog items. Also called backlog grooming, it ensures upcoming work is well-defined and ready for sprint planning.

An approved, snapshot version of a plan component — scope, schedule, or cost — used as a fixed reference point for measuring performance. Changes to baselines require formal approval through the change control process.

The practice of comparing a project's processes, outputs, or metrics against recognized best practices, industry standards, or similar past projects to identify improvement opportunities and realistic performance targets.

A financial indicator that divides the expected benefits of a project by its estimated costs. A BCR greater than 1.0 means anticipated benefits exceed costs. Higher BCR values indicate more financially attractive projects when comparing alternatives.

The ongoing process of ensuring that the intended benefits of a project or program are actually achieved and sustained after closure. It includes defining, planning, measuring, and tracking benefits throughout and beyond the project life cycle.

The total authorized budget allocated to the project. It represents the sum of all planned values and is the baseline denominator for calculating Estimate at Completion, Variance at Completion, and To-Complete Performance Index.

A visual tracking tool that plots remaining work (vertical axis) against time (horizontal axis). As team members complete tasks, the line drops toward zero, giving a clear picture of progress and whether the sprint or release is on track.

A chart that tracks completed work (vertical axis) over time (horizontal axis) alongside a total scope line. Unlike a burndown chart, burnup charts make scope changes visible by showing both the work done and any changes to the total target.

A formal document justifying project initiation by analyzing the problem or opportunity, evaluating solution alternatives, estimating costs and benefits, and recommending a preferred course of action. It serves as the primary basis for senior leadership decisions.

The net quantifiable benefit an organization derives from its investments, encompassing financial returns, improved customer experience, competitive advantages, and operational gains. Delivering business value is the ultimate purpose of project management.

Also called a fishbone or Ishikawa diagram, this quality tool maps potential root causes of a defect or problem, organizing them by category — such as people, process, materials, machines, and environment — to help teams pinpoint and address underlying sources.

A formally authorized group responsible for reviewing, evaluating, approving, deferring, or rejecting proposed changes to the project. The CCB protects the integrity of baselines by ensuring that only beneficial changes are incorporated in a controlled manner.

A formal proposal to modify any project document, deliverable, or baseline. Change requests may arise from identified defects, evolving requirements, or new information, and must be processed through integrated change control before implementation.

A subsidiary plan that defines what information will be communicated, to whom, how frequently, via which channels, and in what format. It ensures stakeholder communication needs are systematically met throughout the project.

The three primary communication methods: Interactive (real-time exchange between two or more parties, e.g., meetings and calls); Push (information sent to recipients without expecting a response, e.g., emails and reports); and Pull (information made available for recipients to access on demand, e.g., portals and repositories).

A formula that calculates the number of potential communication channels in a project: n(n−1)/2, where n is the number of stakeholders. As the team grows, the number of channels grows rapidly, highlighting the importance of structured communication planning.

A system that identifies, tracks, and controls project deliverables and documentation throughout the project life cycle. It maintains baseline integrity and provides a full history of changes to any controlled item.

A limiting condition that restricts the project team's options, such as a fixed end date, capped budget, regulatory requirement, or resource limitation. Unlike assumptions, constraints are established facts rather than beliefs.

A portion of the project budget or schedule set aside to address identified risks that may materialize. Contingency reserves are planned for specific known risks, included within the project baseline, and accessed when those risks occur.

An ongoing commitment to incrementally improving products, processes, and services over time. In project management, it is embedded in agile retrospectives, lessons learned reviews, and quality audits. Supported by methods such as Kaizen and Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA).

Statistical tools that plot process behavior over time, including upper and lower control limits. When data points fall outside these limits or exhibit non-random patterns, the process is considered out of statistical control and investigation is warranted.

The approved, time-phased project budget, excluding management reserve. It represents expected cumulative cost at any point in the project and is used as the reference for measuring cost performance through Earned Value Management.

A project management plan component that specifies how project costs will be planned, estimated, budgeted, financed, managed, monitored, and controlled. It establishes thresholds, reporting formats, and criteria for cost performance measurement.

The total cost of all quality-related activities, including costs to prevent failures (prevention costs), costs to detect failures (appraisal costs), and costs resulting from failures (internal and external failure costs). Reducing COQ generally indicates a more mature quality system.

A cost efficiency ratio calculated as EV ÷ AC. A CPI above 1.0 means the project is delivering more value than it is spending; below 1.0 signals overspending relative to the work accomplished. CPI is one of the most widely used EVM metrics.

A contract type where the buyer pays all allowable costs incurred by the seller plus an agreed-upon fee representing profit. Cost risk rests primarily with the buyer. Best suited when scope cannot be well-defined in advance.

The difference between earned value and actual cost at a specific point in time: CV = EV − AC. A positive CV means the project is under budget for the work completed; a negative CV indicates cost overrun.

A schedule compression technique that reduces project duration by adding resources to critical path activities, accepting increased cost as a trade-off. Unlike fast tracking, crashing keeps activities in their original sequence.
The longest sequence of dependent activities from project start to finish that defines the minimum project duration. Any delay to a critical path activity directly delays the project completion date.

A scheduling algorithm that identifies the longest chain of dependent activities from project start to finish. Activities on this path have zero total float and must finish on time to prevent project delay. CPM is a fundamental tool in predictive project scheduling.

A brief, time-boxed daily meeting (typically 15 minutes) for the development team to synchronize work, share progress, and surface blockers. It is a team coordination event, not a status report to management. The Scrum Master facilitates but does not run it.

A quantitative risk analysis tool that diagrams possible decisions and outcomes, assigning probabilities and monetary values to each branch. The expected monetary value of each branch is calculated to identify the option with the highest expected return.

A shared team agreement on all quality standards, tests, and criteria that must be satisfied for a work item or increment to be considered complete. Without a clear DoD, 'done' means different things to different people, leading to technical debt and rework.

A set of conditions a backlog item must meet before the team can pull it into a sprint. It typically requires sufficient detail, clear acceptance criteria, and a feasible size. Having a DoR reduces mid-sprint clarification delays.

Any unique, verifiable product, result, or capability produced to complete a project, phase, or process. Deliverables may be tangible (documents, hardware, software) or intangible (trained personnel, improved processes).

The method selected to create and evolve project deliverables, ranging from fully predictive (waterfall) to fully adaptive (agile), with hybrid combinations in between. Selection is driven by requirements stability, delivery risk, team capability, and organizational context.

The authorized budget amount for the work that has actually been completed at a specific point in time. EV expresses accomplishment in financial terms, enabling objective comparison with what was planned and what was spent.

An integrated performance measurement system that combines scope, schedule, and cost data to provide an objective, quantitative view of project health. By comparing PV, EV, and AC, teams can calculate variances, efficiency indexes, and forecasts at any point in the project.

The capacity to recognize, understand, manage, and effectively apply one's own emotions and the emotions of others. High EI in project managers supports better conflict resolution, stronger team cohesion, and more productive stakeholder relationships.

Internal and external conditions — outside the project team's direct control — that can influence project outcomes. Examples include organizational culture, market conditions, regulatory requirements, commercial databases, and industry standards.

A large body of work that is too broad to be completed in a single sprint and must be decomposed into smaller user stories or features. Epics represent high-level requirements and serve as containers for organizing related work across multiple iterations.

A forecast of the total project cost based on actual performance to date. The most common formula assumes current efficiency continues: EAC = BAC ÷ CPI. Alternative formulas apply different assumptions about future performance.

The expected cost needed to complete all remaining project work. When calculated from EVM data: ETC = EAC − AC. The team may also re-estimate ETC from scratch when performance assumptions change significantly.

A statistical concept that quantifies the weighted average outcome of an uncertain event by multiplying the probability of occurrence by the financial impact. EMV can be negative (threats) or positive (opportunities) and is summed to evaluate overall risk exposure.

Costs incurred when defects are discovered after the product has been delivered to the customer. Examples include warranty repairs, recalls, rework in the field, and loss of reputation. These are the most expensive category of quality failure costs.

A schedule compression technique that overlaps activities originally planned sequentially, shortening the project duration without adding resources. Fast tracking increases risk because it removes natural buffer time and requires closer coordination between parallel work streams.

A distinct, customer-valued capability of a product that can be planned and developed together. Features are larger than user stories but smaller than epics, and typically represent a meaningful chunk of functionality deliverable across one or a few sprints.

A logical relationship in which a successor activity cannot finish until its predecessor finishes. For example, user acceptance testing cannot finish until development finishes. FF relationships are used in the Precedence Diagramming Method.
The most common logical relationship in project scheduling: a successor activity cannot start until its predecessor finishes. For example, testing cannot begin until coding is complete.

A contract type where the agreed price is set before work begins and does not change regardless of actual costs. Cost risk is borne primarily by the seller. Best suited when scope is well-defined and stable prior to contracting.

The amount of time a scheduled activity can be delayed without causing a negative consequence. Total float measures delay without impacting the project end date; free float measures delay without affecting the earliest start of any successor. Activities on the critical path have zero total float.

The amount of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the earliest start of any immediately following (successor) activity. Free float is always less than or equal to total float and pertains only to the activity's direct successors.

The practice of adding features or functions not included in the approved scope — even if well-intentioned — without going through formal change control. Gold plating wastes resources, may introduce risk, and violates the principle of delivering what was agreed.

The framework of rules, policies, processes, and decision rights by which projects, programs, and portfolios are directed, controlled, and evaluated. Effective governance ensures decisions are made at the right level, accountability is clear, and performance is monitored against strategic intent.

A motivational theory distinguishing between hygiene factors — whose absence causes dissatisfaction (e.g., salary, working conditions, job security) — and motivators — whose presence drives satisfaction and engagement (e.g., achievement, recognition, growth). Removing dissatisfiers alone does not motivate; adding motivators is necessary.
related: McGregor's Theory X and Theory Y

terms.definition: A project delivery method that deliberately combines predictive and adaptive elements, selecting the best practices from each to suit the specific project context. For example, requirements may be gathered predictively while delivery is executed iteratively in sprints.

A delivery method where the product is built and released in successive increments, each adding new, usable functionality to what was previously delivered. Increments build on each other without revisiting completed portions, enabling early delivery of partial value.

A highly visible, publicly accessible display — physical or digital — that shows current work status in a format easily readable by anyone on or around the team. Kanban boards, burndown charts, and task walls are common examples that promote transparency.

The process of reviewing, approving, and managing all change requests by evaluating their impact across the full project — scope, schedule, cost, quality, and risk — before any change is implemented. It ensures changes are handled consistently and baselines remain valid.

Costs incurred to correct defects discovered before the product is delivered to the customer. Examples include rework, scrap, and re-testing. Catching failures internally is far less costly than external failure but still represents waste.

The discount rate at which the net present value of all project cash flows equals zero. A higher IRR signals a more attractive investment. Projects are generally selected when IRR exceeds the organization's required rate of return or hurdle rate.

A current problem, gap, or conflict that is already occurring and requires resolution to avoid negative impact on project objectives. Issues differ from risks in that they are happening now rather than being potential future events.

A project document that tracks all identified issues, their descriptions, owners, priority levels, status, and resolution actions. Maintaining an issue log ensures that no problem falls through the cracks and that accountability is clear.

A delivery method where work is performed in repeating cycles (iterations), with each cycle producing a refined version of the deliverable based on feedback from the previous one. This enables learning and adaptation while progressively improving the output.

A Japanese philosophy meaning 'change for the better,' focused on continuous, incremental improvement involving all team members at all levels. In project management, it supports a culture of small, ongoing improvements rather than large occasional changes.

A visual workflow management system that limits work in progress (WIP) and uses a pull-based approach — work is pulled into active stages only when capacity exists, rather than being pushed by a schedule. Kanban boards make flow and bottlenecks immediately visible.

A delay intentionally introduced between a predecessor and successor activity. For example, in a Finish-to-Start relationship with a five-day lag, the successor cannot start until five days after the predecessor finishes, allowing for curing time or regulatory waiting periods.

An overlap between predecessor and successor activities that allows the successor to begin before the predecessor is fully complete. Lead is represented as a negative lag value and is commonly used to accelerate a schedule without adding resources.

A philosophy and set of practices focused on maximizing value while minimizing waste. Originating in manufacturing (Toyota Production System), Lean principles — including eliminating waste, amplifying learning, and deciding late — influence both agile frameworks and process improvement initiatives.

Knowledge and insights gained during a project — from both successes and failures — that are captured, shared, and used to improve future projects. Lessons learned should be collected continuously, not only at project close.

A living document that records knowledge gained about processes, risks, decisions, and outcomes throughout the project. At closure, it is transferred to the organization's process asset library to benefit future projects.

The total cost of ownership of a project deliverable over its entire operational life, including acquisition, operation, maintenance, and disposal costs. Considering life cycle cost leads to better investment decisions than looking at project costs alone.

Budget held outside the project baseline and reserved for unknown unknowns — risks that were not identified during planning. Accessing management reserve requires management authorization, distinguishing it from contingency reserve which is already in the project budget.

A motivation model proposing that human needs are arranged in a hierarchy: physiological (survival) → safety → social belonging → esteem → self-actualization. Lower-level needs must generally be met before higher-level needs become motivating. It helps managers understand what motivates different team members at different times.
related: McGregor's Theory X and Theory Y

terms.definition: A motivation theory identifying three dominant needs that drive individual behavior: Achievement (the desire to accomplish challenging goals), Affiliation (the need for positive relationships and belonging), and Power (the drive to influence others). Managers can motivate more effectively by recognizing which need dominates each person.

terms.term: McGregor's Theory X and Theory Y
terms.definition: A management framework contrasting two opposing assumptions about workers. Theory X assumes employees are inherently lazy, avoid responsibility, and must be controlled. Theory Y assumes employees are self-motivated, creative, and capable of taking ownership. Modern project management largely embraces Theory Y principles.

A significant point or event in the project schedule — typically the completion of a major deliverable, phase, or key decision — that has zero duration and serves as a checkpoint for reviewing progress and making go/no-go decisions.

The smallest version of a product that delivers enough value to early adopters while generating feedback to guide further development. MVPs allow teams to validate assumptions with real users before committing to full feature development, reducing waste and investment risk.

A quantitative risk analysis technique that runs thousands of simulated scenarios using probability distributions for uncertain inputs (duration or cost ranges) to generate a probability distribution of possible outcomes, showing the likelihood of completing on time or within budget.

The current worth of future cash flows discounted to the present at a required rate of return. A positive NPV indicates the project is expected to generate more value than it costs. When selecting among projects, the one with the highest NPV is typically preferred.

A graphical representation of the logical sequence and dependencies among project activities. Used in Critical Path Method analysis to identify the longest path, float values, and the impact of delays. The most common format is Activity-on-Node (AON) using the Precedence Diagramming Method.

The potential benefit forfeited when one option is chosen over the next best alternative. In project selection, the opportunity cost of approving a project is the best benefit that could have been gained from a competing project that was not funded.

A hierarchical diagram that shows how the project is organized by responsibility, mapping work to organizational units or individuals. When aligned with the WBS, the OBS forms the basis for creating a Responsibility Assignment Matrix (RAM).

The accumulated knowledge, procedures, templates, historical data, and lessons learned owned by the performing organization. OPAs inform how projects are managed and are updated by project outputs to benefit future work.

The result or effect achieved through the completion of a project or process — the change in condition, behavior, or capability for people, systems, or organizations. Outcomes are broader than deliverables: a deliverable is the output, while the outcome is the lasting change it enables.

A combination bar-and-line chart that ranks defect categories or problem causes by frequency, illustrating the 80/20 principle: roughly 80% of problems stem from 20% of causes. It helps quality teams focus improvement efforts on the highest-impact issues first.

The time required to recover the initial project investment from net cash inflows. Shorter payback periods indicate lower financial risk and faster return of capital. Used as a simple screening criterion alongside NPV and IRR in project selection.

The integrated scope-schedule-cost plan that combines all three baselines into a unified performance standard. The PMB is the reference for EVM analysis and excludes management reserve. All EVM metrics compare actual performance against the PMB.

A formal review point at the end of a project phase where senior stakeholders evaluate performance, deliverables, and the viability of proceeding. The outcome may be to continue, redirect, pause, or terminate the project. Also called a stage gate or kill point.

The authorized budget allocated to scheduled work at a specific measurement date. PV represents what the project was planned to have accomplished by that point. It is also known as Budgeted Cost of Work Scheduled (BCWS).

A consensus-based agile estimation technique where team members simultaneously reveal their individual effort estimates (typically using cards with Fibonacci-like values) for a work item. Differences in estimates trigger discussion that converges on a shared understanding and agreed estimate.

An organizational structure that standardizes project governance and facilitates the sharing of resources, methodologies, tools, and information. PMOs range from supportive (advisory), to controlling (mandating standards), to directive (directly managing projects).

A collection of projects, programs, subsidiary portfolios, and operations managed as a group to achieve strategic goals. Portfolio management focuses on selecting the right mix of work to maximize organizational value rather than on individual project delivery.

A stakeholder mapping tool that places stakeholders on a two-axis grid based on their level of authority (power) and their concern for project outcomes (interest). The four resulting quadrants guide the amount of engagement and communication effort to direct toward each group.

A scheduling technique that represents activities as nodes connected by arrows showing dependency relationships. PDM supports four dependency types: Finish-to-Start (FS), Start-to-Start (SS), Finish-to-Finish (FF), and Start-to-Finish (SF).

A project delivery method where scope, schedule, and cost are determined in detail early and work is executed according to a comprehensive plan. Best suited to projects with well-defined requirements, stable technology, and low uncertainty. Also referred to as waterfall or plan-driven.

Costs incurred to prevent defects from occurring in the first place. Examples include training, process design, standards development, and design reviews. Prevention costs are the most cost-effective quality investment — catching a defect early is far cheaper than fixing it later.

A qualitative risk analysis tool that scores each identified risk by combining its probability of occurrence with its potential impact on project objectives. Risks are plotted in a matrix to prioritize which require detailed response strategies.

An ordered, evolving list of everything needed in the product, maintained exclusively by the Product Owner. It is the single source of requirements for all future work. Items at the top are more detailed and immediately actionable; items at the bottom are larger and less refined.

In Scrum, the team member responsible for maximizing product value by managing and prioritizing the product backlog. The Product Owner bridges the gap between stakeholders and the development team, making final decisions about what gets built and in what order.

A group of related projects, subsidiary programs, and program activities managed together to obtain benefits not achievable by managing them individually. Program management coordinates interdependencies between projects and aligns their collective outcomes with strategic goals.

The continuous process of increasing detail in a project plan as more information becomes available. Early in the project, plans may be high-level; as understanding grows, specifics are added. This is a natural feature of all project planning, not a sign of poor preparation.

A temporary endeavor with a defined beginning and end, undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result. Projects differ from ongoing operations in their finite nature and unique objectives. Every project creates something that did not previously exist.

The document that formally authorizes a project's existence and grants the project manager authority to allocate organizational resources. Issued by the sponsor, it documents high-level objectives, success criteria, risks, constraints, and key stakeholders.

The series of phases a project passes through from initiation to closure. The life cycle structure provides a framework for managing and governing project work, with phase gates serving as formal decision points between phases.

The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet project requirements. Effective project management means balancing competing demands across scope, schedule, cost, quality, resources, and risk to deliver value to stakeholders.

The master document describing how the project will be executed, monitored, controlled, and closed. It integrates all subsidiary management plans and baselines into a coherent guide that evolves throughout the project via formal change control.

The individual assigned to lead the project team in achieving project objectives. Responsible for planning, executing, monitoring, controlling, and closing the project, the project manager must balance competing stakeholder needs and act as a bridge between the team and senior leadership.

A high-level visual summary showing key milestones, deliverables, and timing across the project or product at a strategic level. A roadmap communicates direction and priorities without prescribing every execution detail.

A Responsibility Assignment Matrix that clarifies roles for each project activity or deliverable using four designations: Responsible (does the work), Accountable (owns the outcome and makes final decisions), Consulted (provides input), and Informed (kept in the loop). Each task should have exactly one Accountable party.

A formal procurement document used when the buyer cannot fully define requirements and wants sellers to propose solutions. An RFP includes the problem statement, evaluation criteria, and contract requirements. Sellers respond with a formal proposal outlining their approach, qualifications, and pricing.

Conditions or capabilities that a product, service, or result must satisfy to meet stakeholder needs or contractual obligations. Requirements are elicited, documented, and validated before being incorporated into the approved project scope.

A schedule optimization technique that adjusts activity start and finish dates to resolve resource over-allocation. Resource leveling may extend the project duration but ensures no team member or resource is scheduled beyond their capacity in any given time period.

A schedule optimization technique that adjusts resource usage within the available float of activities to reduce peak demand, without extending the project end date. Unlike resource leveling, it does not delay the critical path or change the project duration.

A matrix that maps project scope components to the team members or groups responsible for completing them. The most common form is the RACI matrix. The RAM ensures that every work package has a clear owner and that accountability is unambiguous.

A structured team meeting held at the end of an iteration or project phase where the team reflects on their process, identifies what went well, what could be improved, and commits to specific changes in the next cycle. It is the core mechanism for continuous improvement in agile.

An uncertain event or condition that, if it occurs, will have a positive or negative effect on project objectives. Negative risks are called threats; positive risks are opportunities. All projects carry inherent risk due to their unique and temporary nature.

The degree of uncertainty an organization or stakeholder is willing to accept in pursuit of a reward. Organizations with high risk appetite tolerate greater uncertainty for potentially greater gain; those with low risk appetite prefer more predictable, conservative outcomes.

The primary project document for tracking all identified risks, including their descriptions, categories, probability and impact ratings, prioritization, response plans, owners, triggers, and current status. It is updated continuously throughout the project life cycle.

Planned actions to address identified risks. For threats: Avoid (change plans to eliminate the risk), Transfer (shift risk to a third party via insurance or contract), Mitigate (reduce probability or impact), or Accept (acknowledge without proactive action). For opportunities: Exploit, Share, Enhance, or Accept.

A progressive elaboration technique where near-term work is planned in fine detail while distant work is planned at a high level, with detail added as the work approaches. It acknowledges that precise planning of far-future work is often premature and wasteful.

A stakeholder analysis tool that classifies stakeholders based on three attributes: Power (ability to impose their will), Legitimacy (appropriateness of their engagement), and Urgency (time-sensitivity of their needs). Stakeholders who score high on all three are the most 'salient' and require the most attention.

The approved version of the project schedule model, fixed at a point in time and changeable only through formal change control. It is used as the reference for measuring schedule performance and calculating Schedule Variance.

A schedule efficiency ratio calculated as EV ÷ PV. An SPI above 1.0 indicates the project is completing more work than planned for the period; below 1.0 means it is behind schedule. SPI measures schedule efficiency in budget terms, not calendar time.

The difference between earned value and planned value at a measurement date: SV = EV − PV. A positive SV indicates the project is ahead of schedule; a negative SV means it is behind. Because SV is expressed in monetary terms, it eventually reaches zero at project completion regardless of actual schedule performance.

An approved, integrated package consisting of the project scope statement, the Work Breakdown Structure, and the WBS dictionary. It is the reference for measuring scope performance and can only be changed through formal change control.

The uncontrolled expansion of project scope — often through small, informal changes — without corresponding adjustments to schedule, cost, or resources. Scope creep typically results from bypassing the formal change control process and is one of the most common causes of project overruns.

An agile framework that organizes work into time-boxed sprints (1–4 weeks) with three defined roles (Product Owner, Scrum Master, Development Team), three artifacts (Product Backlog, Sprint Backlog, Increment), and five events (Sprint, Sprint Planning, Daily Scrum, Sprint Review, Sprint Retrospective).

A servant-leader role in Scrum responsible for ensuring the team understands and adheres to the Scrum framework, removing organizational impediments, coaching on agile principles, and shielding the team from disruptive external influences. The Scrum Master is not a traditional manager.

A leadership approach that places the needs of the team above the leader's own agenda. A servant leader focuses on empowering team members, removing obstacles, developing individuals, and creating the conditions for high performance — rather than directing, controlling, or taking credit.

A data-driven quality methodology that targets process improvement by reducing defect rates to below 3.4 defects per million opportunities — the statistical 'six sigma' level. It uses DMAIC (Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, Control) for improving existing processes and DMADV for designing new ones.

The individual or group that provides resources and support for the project and is ultimately accountable for its success at the organizational level. The sponsor authorizes the project charter, champions the project with leadership, removes high-level obstacles, and makes executive decisions.

A fixed, time-boxed period (typically 1–4 weeks) in Scrum during which the team builds a potentially releasable product increment. Each sprint starts with a planning event, ends with a review and retrospective, and is driven by a clear sprint goal.

The set of product backlog items selected for the current sprint, along with the team's detailed plan for completing them and achieving the sprint goal. The sprint backlog is owned by the development team and updated daily as progress and understanding evolve.

A Scrum event at the start of each sprint where the team selects backlog items, agrees on a sprint goal, and breaks selected items into tasks. The output is a committed sprint backlog with a realistic, achievable scope for the time-box.

A Scrum event held after the sprint review and before the next sprint, where the team inspects its own process and collaboration patterns, identifies what worked and what didn't, and commits to at least one specific improvement in the next sprint.

A Scrum event held at the end of each sprint where the team demonstrates the completed increment to stakeholders, gathers feedback, and collaborates on updating the product backlog. It is a working session designed to inspect the outcome and adapt the product direction.

Any individual, group, or organization that may affect, be affected by, or perceive themselves to be affected by a project decision, activity, or outcome. Stakeholders hold varying degrees of interest, influence, and authority, and must be actively engaged throughout the project.

A subsidiary project plan that describes the strategies, actions, and communication approaches for effectively engaging stakeholders throughout the project, based on their needs, interests, and current level of engagement versus the desired engagement level.

A project document containing information about all identified stakeholders, including contact details, roles, interests, expectations, levels of influence, and current engagement status. It is the foundation for all stakeholder management planning.

A rarely used logical relationship in which the successor activity cannot finish until the predecessor activity has started. It is most commonly seen in just-in-time scheduling and shift handover scenarios.

A logical relationship in which a successor activity cannot start until its predecessor has started. SS relationships are used when work can begin in parallel, but the successor must wait for the predecessor to initiate. For example, writing can begin after editing has started.

A narrative document describing the work to be performed by a contractor or project team, including specific deliverables, timelines, location, applicable standards, and acceptance criteria. The SOW is typically incorporated into or attached to a contract.

A relative unit used by agile teams to estimate the size or complexity of a backlog item. Story points capture effort, complexity, and uncertainty as a single measure. Teams use their velocity (points completed per sprint) to forecast when work will be done.

Money already spent that cannot be recovered. A fundamental principle in decision-making is that sunk costs should not influence future choices — only future costs and benefits should drive decisions. Continuing a failing project simply to justify past spending is a cognitive bias, not rational management.

The intentional adaptation of project management approaches, processes, governance, tools, and methods to fit the unique context, culture, complexity, and constraints of a specific project. Effective tailoring avoids both under-management (too little process) and over-management (too much process).

The implied cost of rework resulting from shortcuts or quick fixes implemented now instead of proper solutions. Like financial debt, technical debt accrues interest in the form of increasing complexity and maintenance burden over time. Agile teams actively manage technical debt to sustain development velocity.

An estimating technique that uses three estimates — Optimistic (O), Most Likely (M), and Pessimistic (P) — to calculate a weighted average duration or cost. The PERT formula is: (O + 4M + P) ÷ 6. It accounts for estimation uncertainty better than single-point estimates.

A hybrid contract that combines elements of both fixed-price and cost-reimbursable structures. The buyer pays for actual labor at fixed hourly or daily rates, plus actual material costs. Appropriate when scope cannot be defined in advance but some pricing structure is needed.

A scheduling technique that fixes the duration of an activity or iteration in advance, adjusting scope to fit within that window rather than extending time to complete a fixed scope. Sprints are the most prominent example — the team delivers the best possible outcome within the sprint's fixed length.

The required cost efficiency ratio for remaining work to meet the project's budget goal. TCPI = (BAC − EV) ÷ (BAC − AC). A TCPI above 1.0 means future work must be performed more efficiently than in the past to avoid a cost overrun.

The total amount of time an activity can be delayed from its early start without delaying the project end date or violating a schedule constraint. Activities on the critical path have zero total float — any delay directly delays the project.

A model describing the typical progression of team dynamics: Forming (polite orientation), Storming (conflict and competition), Norming (developing cohesion and norms), Performing (high-trust, high-productivity), and Adjourning (dissolution at project end). Teams may cycle back to earlier stages when membership or goals change significantly.

A brief, informal description of a product feature from the perspective of a specific user, written in the format: 'As a [user type], I want [capability] so that [benefit].' User stories promote conversation and shared understanding rather than detailed specification documents.

The worth, utility, or importance of something relative to a stakeholder or organization. In PMBOK® 8th edition, delivering value is the purpose of project management — encompassing financial returns, organizational improvements, customer satisfaction, and social or environmental benefits, not merely the completion of tasks.

The projected difference between the total budget and the expected final cost of the project: VAC = BAC − EAC. A positive VAC forecasts an under-budget completion; a negative VAC signals a projected cost overrun.

The amount of work (typically measured in story points) a scrum team completes per sprint. Tracking velocity over multiple sprints helps teams make realistic commitments, forecast release dates, and identify process improvements. Velocity is a planning tool for the team, not a performance measure for management.

A companion document to the Work Breakdown Structure that provides detailed information about each WBS component, including scope description, deliverables, assigned resources, cost estimates, schedule milestones, and quality requirements.

A constraint in Kanban that caps the number of work items permitted in any workflow stage at one time. WIP limits force the team to finish existing work before starting new items, expose bottlenecks, and maintain a consistent flow of value delivery.

A hierarchical decomposition of the total project scope into progressively smaller components, down to work packages that can be scheduled, cost-estimated, monitored, and controlled. The WBS represents 100% of the scope — nothing more, nothing less.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. Project managers and team members act as responsible stewards of organizational resources — including time, money, materials, and reputation — managing them with integrity, diligence, and care for both short-term and long-term consequences.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. Build a collaborative project team environment characterized by shared ownership, psychological safety, mutual respect, and diversity of thought. Teams that trust each other consistently outperform collections of individuals working in silos.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. Actively and proactively engage with stakeholders throughout the project. Understanding their interests, expectations, and concerns — and addressing them appropriately — is essential for delivering outcomes that create real value.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. Continuously evaluate and align work to the outcomes that matter most. Value delivery goes beyond delivering on schedule and budget — it means producing outcomes that genuinely benefit the organization and its stakeholders.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. View the project as part of a broader system, recognizing how components interact with each other and with the surrounding environment. Changes in one part of the system create ripple effects that must be anticipated and managed.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. Demonstrate and foster effective leadership behaviors — motivation, coaching, empowerment, and vision — throughout the project. Leadership is not limited to the project manager; anyone on the team can and should lead when the situation calls for it.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. Intentionally adapt the project approach, governance, and processes to fit the unique context of each project. No single methodology suits every situation — thoughtful tailoring finds the right balance between rigor and flexibility.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. Build quality into both processes and deliverables from the outset. Quality is everyone's responsibility, achieved through prevention, inspection, and continuous improvement — not as an afterthought or a separate team's job.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. Recognize, evaluate, and navigate complexity by applying appropriate tools, techniques, and judgment. Complex projects involve emergent behavior, ambiguity, and interconnected factors that cannot be fully anticipated — requiring adaptive responses rather than rigid plans.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. Proactively identify, evaluate, and respond to both threats and opportunities. Managing risk is not a one-time event but a continuous discipline that protects project objectives while also enabling teams to pursue upside potential.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. Build the capacity to anticipate and respond to disruptions, setbacks, and change without losing momentum toward project goals. Resilient teams absorb shocks, learn quickly, and adapt their approach rather than failing when conditions change.

One of the 12 PMBOK® 8th edition principles. Embrace and enable change when it is necessary to realize the intended benefits. This means preparing people for change, managing transition thoughtfully, and helping the organization move from its current state to the desired future state.

One of the 8 PMBOK® 8th edition performance domains. Addresses how the project team builds productive relationships with stakeholders throughout the project, understanding their needs and expectations, engaging them appropriately, and managing their involvement to ensure positive project outcomes.

One of the 8 PMBOK® 8th edition performance domains. Addresses activities and responsibilities related to developing, building, and maintaining an effective, motivated, and high-performing project team. Covers leadership, team culture, accountability, and team growth.

terms.term: Development Approach and Life Cycle Performance Domain
terms.definition: One of the 8 PMBOK® 8th edition performance domains. Addresses the selection and application of the appropriate project delivery approach — predictive, hybrid, or adaptive — and the structuring of the project life cycle to best serve stakeholder needs and project context.

One of the 8 PMBOK® 8th edition performance domains. Addresses all activities involved in initially and continuously organizing and coordinating project work — including scope, schedule, cost, resources, and risk — to ensure the team delivers what was agreed.

One of the 8 PMBOK® 8th edition performance domains. Addresses the activities required to establish and maintain the project work processes needed to produce deliverables efficiently. Covers day-to-day execution, resource management, procurement, and stakeholder communications.

One of the 8 PMBOK® 8th edition performance domains. Addresses activities and responsibilities related to delivering scope and quality in a way that meets stakeholder requirements and achieves the intended business outcomes and value.

One of the 8 PMBOK® 8th edition performance domains. Addresses activities for assessing project performance and implementing necessary adjustments. Effective measurement uses meaningful metrics to understand progress, identify trends, and forecast outcomes — rather than reporting for its own sake.

One of the 8 PMBOK® 8th edition performance domains. Addresses activities and responsibilities for identifying, evaluating, and responding to threats and opportunities arising from uncertainty, ambiguity, and complexity throughout the project life cycle.

Approaches for managing disagreements within a project team. Five key techniques in order of general effectiveness: Collaborating/Problem Solving (finding a win-win solution — most preferred), Compromising (each party gives something up), Smoothing/Accommodating (playing down differences), Forcing/Directing (imposing a solution), and Withdrawing/Avoiding (retreating from the conflict — least effective).

A technique that breaks project deliverables or work down into smaller, more manageable components. Used to create the Work Breakdown Structure and to subdivide user stories into tasks. Decomposition continues until each piece is small enough to be estimated, assigned, and completed within a manageable timeframe.

The final phase of the project life cycle where all activities are formally completed, deliverables are transferred or handed over, contracts are closed, final documentation is archived, and lessons learned are captured. Closure formally releases project resources and confirms that all obligations have been fulfilled.
